learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate your understanding of major concepts and theories of international development, including by applying them to explain contemporary development-related debates and issues.
Discuss how intersecting social location shapes development experiences in post-colonial and settler colonial societies
Explain the causes of, and imagine diverse responses to, experiences of global inequalities
Analyse the interconnections between environmental and social justice in development debates
Apply development ethics in analysing global development issues
Practice careful listening and respectful engagement with others, as part of demonstrating your understanding of the importance of collective learning environments.

assessments.assessment_title: Concepts and Theories of Development Exam
assessments.due_date:
2/04/2026

The in-class exam begins at 10:00 AM and concludes at 10:45 AM on 02/04/2026.
assessments.task_description:
A short answer in class exam will be held in week 6 (Thursday 2 April). Questions will require students to showcase learnings related to key theories and development debates covered in the course up to and including week 6. This will be in class, with students required to hand write answers. There will be 3 questions, worth 10 marks (10%) each. Students will be required to write 300 words per answer, a total of 900 words Max. A printed copy of the exam and paper for answers will be provided.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.weighting: <dd>30% 5 min questions and answers with course convenor </dd>
assessments.due_date:
16/04/2026 - 28/05/2026

Student question and answer sessions will run from week 7 (16 April) - week 13 (28 May). Students will be allocated a time slot between week 7 and 13 where they will be required to attend a question and answer session with the course convenor, to directly respond to aspects of their selected book. All question and answer sessions will be recorded.
assessments.task_description:
You are required to select one book from the list below to read as part of your learning in this course. You do not need to have completely finished reading the book at the time of your question and answer session, but you will be required to have completed a significant portion of it.

This task is a question and answer session with the course convenor. Each student will be required to meet the convenor at an agreed time slot to answer a series of short questions in direct relation to your chosen book. You will be required to give succinct answers that show your familiarity with the book, your engagement with its purpose and intended audience, and the way you understand it connects with theories and concepts of globalisation and development in post colonial societies.

You are strongly advised to select your book by no later than the end of week 2, so that you can ensure you have read a substantial portion prior to your question and answer session. Question and answer sessions will proceed in the third hour of our scheduled lecture time (starting in week 7, from 10 - 11am, each week, in class time).

The Books:

Ghosh, A. (2021) The Nutmeg's Curse. Parables for a Planet in Crisis. The University of Chicago Press. 

Klein, N. (2023) Doppelganger. A Trip into the Mirror World. Penguin Books. 

Marya, R. and Patel, R. (2021) Inflamed. Deep Medicine and the Anatomy of Injustice. Farrar, Straus and Giroux, New York. 

McKenna, M. (2021) 'Return to Uluru' Black Inc. Victoria. 

Shiva, Vandana, (2016) 'Who Really Feeds the World? The Failures of Agribusiness and the Promise of AgroEcology', North Atlantic Books, USA.  

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
At the end of each Seminar class, you will be required to reflect on your weekly learnings. This will include reflecting on content delivered by the lecturer, in class discussion and set readings for the week. You should aim to write 200 words each week (some weeks you might find you want to write in sentences, other weeks perhaps you will want to draw a diagram, or a picture, to reflect your learnings). You will have the opportunity to receive feedback on your writing around week 3, with your reflections journal marked at the end of semester.

To assist you in this activity, you should engage with some (or all) of these questions each week:

- What are the key themes and ideas you have learnt about this week (for example in the readings, through lecture content or in class discussion)? 

- Was there anything that particularly excited and/or challenged you this week, that you would like to talk about, including related to your values, or about yourself more broadly?

- Are there aspects of course content that raise ethical questions for you? 

The reflections journal is expected to be undertaken weekly, starting in week 1 and ending in week 12. Each week you will write 200 words (week 1 - 12), adding to a total of 2400 words. Prior to your submission, please select your 9 best weeks (1800 words) of reflection, which will then be marked. To ensure the marker knows which weeks you have selected, please clearly highlight or mark, or provide and index and/or statement at the start of your reflection journal to guide the reader.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assessment. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date. Prior to your submission, please select your 9 best weeks (1800 words) of reflection, which will then be marked. To ensure the marker knows which weeks you have selected, please clearly highlight or mark, or provide and index and/or statement at the start of your reflection journal to guide the reader.
